div.l: All were he snebbed bothe Erly and late
And some tyme ledde with revell to newgate
But at the laste his maister hym be thought
Vppon a day when he his pauper sought
Of a prouerbe that seyth this same worde
Wele bette is appell oute of horde
Than it rote all the remnaunte
So fare it by a royetous seruaunte
It is lesse harme to lette hym passe
Than he shende all the seruauntꝭes in the place
Therfore his maister yaf all his quitaıı̄unce
And bade hym go with sorowe and mysschaıı̄unce
And thus this Ioly prentice hadde his leve
Nowe lete hym ryote all the nyght or leve
And for is no thefe with outyn a looke
That helpeth hym to wasten and to souke
Of that he can begge or borowe may
Anoone he sente his bedde and his array
Vnto a conper of his owne sorte
That louede this revelle and disporte
And hadde a wyfe that helde for coıı̄untenaunce
A shoppe and swyved for hir sustenaunce

note.note: Pointing hand to bracketed final couplet

div.l: But here of I wil passe as nowe
And of yonge Gamelyn I will telle you
¶ Here endeth the prologe of the Coke
And here begynneth his tale
Lyte and listen and herken a right
And ye shull here of a dughti knyght
Sir Iohn of burdenxs was his name
He couthe of norture and of myche game
Thre sonnes the knyght hadde and wᵗith his body hem wan
The eldest was a shrewe and soone he began
His brethern loued wele her Fader and of hym werne agaste
The eldest disserued his Faders curse and hadde it at the laste
The good knyght his Fader leuede so yore
That dethe was comen hym to and handyls hym ful sore
The good knyght cared so sore and siked there he lay
Howe his childern shulde lyve after his day
He hadde bene wyde where but none housbonde he was
All the lande that he hadde it was purchace
Fayn he wolde it were dressed betwene hem all
That iche of hem hadde his parte as it myght falle
Tho sente he in the contre after wise knyghtes
